questions.text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of 4 episodes of vomiting that occurred that morning. The parents report that the vomit was yellowish-green with no blood in it. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has generally been healthy. He has passed normal stools each day. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears irritable and pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, mildly distended abdomen with no masses or organomegaly. A nasogastric tube is inserted, and intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT imaging should not be performed on this patient. This patient has features that are most concerning for an anatomical obstruction in the midgut, and other diagnostic tests provide better visualization of this region. Moreover, a CT scan would expose this neonate to unnecessary radiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopy would be indicated if further diagnostic workup did not establish a definitive diagnosis or was suggestive of malrotation with a complicating volvulus. In this neonate, further studies should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal contrast series is the most sensitive exam to visualize the duodenum in infants and the gold standard for diagnosis of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus. The obvious signs of malrotation are a misplaced ligament of Treitz and duodenojejunal junction on the right of the midline. A twisted and thus corkscrew-like appearance of the duodenum and duodenal blockage with a distended stomach would reflect midgut volvulus. See “Imaging in intestinal malrotation and midgut volvulus” table.

Given this neonate's hemodynamic stability, there is no indication for emergency surgery, but the Ladd procedure is recommended as soon as possible to minimize the risk of future volvulus.
Image Description:

Fluoroscopy (upper GI series)

The distal duodenum and proximal jejunum has a spiral configuration (green overlay) and fail to cross the midline into the left upper quadrant. This appearance, referred to as the corkscrew sign, is produced by the twisting of small bowel loops on a shortened mesentery.

The corkscrew sign is characteristic of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus.

D) INCORRECT:

Water-soluble contrast enema is used as a confirmatory test and therapeutic tool for intussusception, which also manifests in infants with vomiting. However, as most cases of intussusception are ileocecal, bilious vomiting occurs only in progressive disease. Additionally, patients typically present between 3–12 months of age and usually also have acute cyclical abdominal pain (every 15–30 minutes) and possibly a palpable mass on abdominal exam.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergency exploratory laparotomy is indicated in cases of hemodynamic instability and/or bowel ischemia or perforation. This patient is hemodynamically stable, is afebrile, and has a soft abdomen, indicating that further diagnostic workup is safe. Should he decompensate and develop profound tachycardia, hypotension, signs of perforation (e.g., free air under the diaphragm on repeat plain film), or signs of bowel infarction (e.g. hematochezia), emergency surgery would be indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is an important imaging modality for differentiating between causes of abdominal pain in children. It is most helpful in establishing the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, which also manifests with acute-onset emesis and abdominal pain. Classically, an olive-shaped mass can be felt on abdominal exam; this patient's abdominal exam is notable for mild distention but no mass is evident. Moreover, the patient described here has bilious vomiting, a finding that is less likely with an obstruction caused by a hypertrophic pylorus, which is proximal to the ampulla of Vater and is therefore more commonly associated with nonbilious vomiting. While ultrasonography can be used in the diagnosis of intestinal malrotation and midgut volvulus, it is not the most sensitive diagnostic technique. For this reason, it is not the most appropriate next step in management.

G) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy is used to treat sigmoid volvulus in patients who have no signs or symptoms of peritonitis (e.g., rebound tenderness, hemodynamic instability). Sigmoid volvulus is most commonly seen in elderly adults and manifests with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and bloating. This young patient most likely has a more proximal intestinal pathology, meaning that sigmoidoscopy would not be appropriate.
questions.hint: This 3-week-old neonate presents with acute-onset bilious vomiting and a mildly distended abdomen, which should raise suspicion for midgut obstruction, most likely due to intestinal malrotation.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the emergency room because of 4 episodes of bilious vomiting and inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. An upper GI contrast series shows the duodenojejunal junction to the right of the vertebral midline; an air-filled cecum is noted in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud
Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter
Resorption of a small bowel segment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective neural crest migration to the distal colon results in Hirschsprung disease. The aganglionic segment of the colon fails to relax, which causes functional intestinal obstruction. Although Hirschsprung disease would manifest with bilious vomiting, it also causes significant abdominal distension. Moreover, it typically manifests right after birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours or later in childhood with constipation and abdominal distention.
Image Description:

Distended, bulging abdomen that is tender on palpation. Diagnosis performed by rectal suction biopsy: Hirschsprung's disease

B) INCORRECT:

Failure of duodenal recanalization results in duodenal atresia, which would manifest with complete intestinal obstruction at birth. Hallmark imaging findings are the double bubble sign as well as a completely gasless distal small bowel, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, duodenal atresia is associated with maternal polyhydramnios.
Image Description:

X-ray of the abdomen

Dilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

C) INCORRECT:

With complete nonrotation of the intestine, the cecum usually remains in the left lower quadrant. However, this patient's GI series shows a cecum located in the right upper quadrant. Patients with nonrotation may be asymptomatic or present with varying degrees of small bowel obstruction. Radiologically, the small bowel is seen to occupy the right side of the abdomen, with the colon predominantly on the left.

D) CORRECT:

Incomplete intestinal rotation, indicated by a malpositioned duodenojejunal junction (usually located to the left of the midline) and cecum (normally located in the right lower quadrant), can manifest as duodenal obstruction, causing bilious vomiting without abdominal distension. Obstruction is due to extrinsic duodenal compression by peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) that cross over the duodenum to fix the abnormal cecum to the liver or peritoneum.
Image Description:

The types of volvulus are classified by anatomical location as illustrated here.

- Midgut volvulus: A malrotated midgut causing mechanical bowel obstruction, mostly in neonates and infants. Fibrous peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) attaching the cecum to the retroperitoneum are a common pathological finding in midgut volvulus.

- Cecal volvulus: The cecum rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

- Sigmoid volvulus: The sigmoid colon rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

E) INCORRECT:

An arrested ventral pancreatic bud rotation causes annular pancreas, which can result in extrinsic compression of the duodenum, usually proximal to the major duodenal papilla. Unlike this patient, neonates with annular pancreas typically present with nonbilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Findings on an upper GI series include eccentric or concentric narrowing of the second portion of the duodenum, double bubble sign, and symmetrical dilatation of the proximal duodenum. Moreover, annular pancreas is associated with maternal polyhydramnios.
Image Description:

Upper GI series (single contrast; lateral view)

Narrowing of the second (descending) portion of the duodenum (white arrow) remained fixed during fluoroscopy. A CT scan (not shown) revealed an annular pancreas as the cause.

DB: duodenal bulb; S: stomach

F) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter lead to pyloric stenosis, which can cause gastric outlet obstruction. Unlike this patient, infants with pyloric stenosis typically present at 2–6 weeks of age with nonbilious vomiting. Other symptoms include early satiety, progressive gastric dilation, weight loss, a succussion splash, and/or hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
Image Description:

In newborns with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, an enlarged, thickened, olive-shaped, nontender pylorus may be palpable in the epigastrium. The primary symptom of the condition is projectile, nonbilious vomiting immediately after feeding.

G) INCORRECT:

Jejunal atresia and ileal atresia occur as a result of resorption of a small bowel segment thought to be caused by an in-utero vascular disruption that leads to ischemic necrosis of the fetal intestine. The necrotic tissue is resorbed, leaving blind proximal and distal ends, often with a gap in the mesentery. Although neonates may present with bilious vomiting as in this case, jejunal/ileal atresia would also cause a distension of the upper abdomen, delayed meconium passage, and a triple bubble sign on x-ray. Moreover, jejunal/ileal atresia has been associated with maternal polyhydramnios.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting

Dilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.

1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level
questions.hint: The duodenojejunal junction normally lies to the left of the midline, adjacent to the vertebral bodies.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy presents with increased irritability and vomiting. He is admitted to the general pediatrics unit with concern for dehydration presumed to be related to viral gastroenteritis.
On day 2 of his hospitalization, he develops bilious emesis and increased abdominal pain after having two bloody stools in the morning. His abdomen is distended and exquisitely tender to palpation. He has a heart rate of 170 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 65/35 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 95% while breathing ambient air.
A nasogastric tube is placed.
In addition to initiating intravenous fluids, what is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If a patient with suspected malrotation is hemodynamically stable with no evidence of peritonitis or bowel ischemia, further imaging is warranted to diagnose malrotation. An upper gastrointestinal (GI) contrast series is considered the gold standard for diagnosing malrotation (sensitivity, 98%) because it is the best way to visualize the duodenum in infants and children. Findings that are indicative of malrotation on a GI series include a clearly misplaced duodenum with the ligament of Treitz on the right side, a duodenum with a corkscrew appearance, or duodenal obstruction where the duodenum may have a beak-like appearance.

B) INCORRECT:

An air-contrast enema would be considered both diagnostic and therapeutic if there were high suspicion for intussusception, but there is no such suspicion in this case.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation — bilious emesis, hematochezia, and abdominal distention — is consistent with a diagnosis of intestinal malrotation with volvulus and bowel ischemia. Given the patient's hemodynamic instability, the most appropriate next step is fluid resuscitation and emergency laparotomy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for intestinal malrotation with volvulus in a hemodynamically unstable infant is immediate laparotomy.

D) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease. Although this patient’s hematochezia could be a sign of inflammatory bowel disease, the acute nature of the presentation is not consistent with colitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is often used to diagnose intussusception, but this diagnosis is unlikely in this patient given his young age and bilious emesis. Signs of malrotation on ultrasound include a misplaced third portion of the duodenum or abnormal position of the superior mesenteric vein, but a normal ultrasound cannot exclude malrotation. Volvulus can be visualized as a dilated duodenum or duodenal obstruction with distal air.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant presents with a 6-hour history of bilious vomiting and fussiness. The parents report normal feeding patterns until yesterday, when the infant began refusing feeds intermittently. Physical examination shows a quiet, alert infant with mild abdominal distention. Vital signs are BP, 80/50; P, 150; R, 30; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. The infant has no signs of dehydration and appears well-perfused. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Upper gastrointestinal series is the gold standard for diagnosing midgut volvulus and may show findings such as corkscrew duodenum, bird beak sign, and incomplete duodenal obstruction. While ultrasound may be considered as an initial bedside test, upper GI series can provide a definitive diagnosis in stable patients with suspected midgut volvulus.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal x-ray shows nonspecific findings in midgut volvulus and may demonstrate signs of bowel obstruction or a gasless abdomen. However, a normal bowel gas pattern does not exclude malrotation or volvulus, making abdominal x-ray insufficient for definitive diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

CT abdomen with contrast is used for diagnosing midgut volvulus in adults and may show the whirlpool sign, but it is not the first-line imaging modality in stable neonates and infants.

D) INCORRECT:

Contrast enema may demonstrate abnormal cecal position in malrotation but is not the appropriate initial diagnostic study for suspected midgut volvulus in stable newborns with bilious vomiting.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyloric ultrasound is used to diagnose hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which manifests with a palpable olive-shaped mass and nonbilious vomiting. This infant has bilious vomiting, which suggests obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater and makes pyloric stenosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe epigastric pain and abdominal distention. She reports multiple episodes of dry retching but has been unable to produce any vomit. She appears uncomfortable and diaphoretic. Physical examination reveals marked epigastric tenderness and distention. Multiple attempts to place a nasogastric tube are unsuccessful due to inability to advance the tube into the stomach. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute pancreatitis manifests with severe epigastric pain and nausea, but patients typically can vomit and nasogastric tube placement, if performed, is usually successful.

B) INCORRECT:

Boerhaave syndrome involves esophageal rupture and typically presents with severe chest pain after forceful vomiting. Patients would have been able to vomit initially, and NG tube placement difficulty would be due to esophageal injury rather than gastric outlet obstruction.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient presents with the classic Borchardt triad: severe epigastric pain and distention, retching without vomiting, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube. This triad is pathognomonic for acute gastric volvulus, which occurs when the stomach rotates more than 180° along one of its axes, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastroparesis causes delayed gastric emptying and can manifest with nausea and vomiting but typically does not present with the triad of epigastric pain and distention, retching, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

E) INCORRECT:

Small bowel obstruction may manifest with abdominal pain, distention, and vomiting, but NG tube placement is typically successful and tenderness is generally not limited to the epigastrium.
